docs.title: University of Minnesota EECD Senior Projects
2026 Sprint Semester
docs.text: This year we will be using Claude Code Skills to generate an intelligent textbook. Each student will be required to build a textbook for a professor at the University of Minnesota. See the details here.

docs.title: 2025 Spring Semester
docs.text: Designing and Building Intelligent Textbooks - where students us generative AI to build intelligent textbooks.

docs.title: 2024 Spring Semester
docs.text:
EE MicroSims - where students used generative AI to create MicroSims for various EE courses.

AI Racing League Upgrade - where students trained RC cars with cameras to drive autonomously around a track and upgraded our online curriculum to support the Raspberry Pi 4.

docs.text:

Thanks! - Dan

docs.title: Adder
docs.text: A digital circuit that performs addition of numbers, typically binary.

docs.title: ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit)
docs.text: A combinational circuit that performs arithmetic and logical operations on binary inputs.

docs.title: Boolean Algebra
docs.text: A branch of mathematics dealing with variables that have two distinct values (true/false or 1/0).

docs.title: Clock Signal
docs.text: A periodic signal used to synchronize the operations of digital circuits.

docs.title: Combinational Logic
docs.text: Logic circuits whose output depends only on the current inputs, not on previous input history.

docs.title: D Flip-Flop
docs.text: A memory element that captures the value of the D-input at a particular edge of the clock signal.

docs.title: Decoder
docs.text: A circuit that converts coded inputs into coded outputs where the output lines are mutually exclusive.

docs.title: Encoder
docs.text: A circuit that converts active input signals into a coded output.

docs.title: Finite State Machine (FSM)
docs.text: A computational model consisting of a finite number of states and transitions based on inputs.

docs.title: Full Adder
docs.text: A digital circuit that adds three binary bits, producing a sum and a carry output.

docs.title: Hazard
docs.text: A temporary fluctuation in output when inputs change in a digital logic circuit, often due to delays.

docs.title: Latch
docs.text: A basic memory device that can store one bit of information and maintains its output until changed.

docs.title: Logic Gate
docs.text: A fundamental building block of digital circuits that performs a basic logical function like AND, OR, or NOT.

docs.title: Minterm
docs.text: A product (AND combination) of all the variables in a Boolean function, either in true or complemented form, representing a single row in the truth table where the output is 1.

docs.title: Multiplexer (MUX)
docs.text: A combinational circuit that selects one of many inputs and forwards it to a single output line.

docs.title: Register
docs.text: A group of flip-flops used to store multiple bits of data.

docs.title: Setup Time
docs.text: The minimum time before the clock edge that the input signal must be held stable to ensure proper operation of a flip-flop.

docs.title: Synchronous Circuit
docs.text: A digital circuit where changes in the state are triggered by a clock signal.

docs.title: Timing Diagram
docs.text: A graphical representation of the relationships between signals and time in a digital circuit.

docs.title: Verilog
docs.text: A hardware description language (HDL) used to model electronic systems.

docs.title: Intelligent Textbooks Proposal
docs.text:
Title: University of Minnesota EECD Senior Seminar Project Proposal 2024

Project Name: Intelligent Textbooks for Electrical Engineering

Facilitator: Dan McCreary

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This project will allow participating students to create a set of intelligent textbooks that embrace the modern use of generative AI. The output of this project will be the foundation of an intelligent textbook for each student who participates.  Students will gain a deep understanding of how to create high-quality prompts that extract precise knowledge from large-language models and store this information in an open format on GitHub with a textbook rendered on GitHub pages.  No prior programming experience is required, but students must work with faculty that are subject-matter experts in a specific course.

docs.title: Details
docs.text:
We propose that one of the groups in the EECD Senior seminar build a series of "Intelligent Textbooks" using generative AI.  Last year, we had two groups participate.  One group built MicroSims and did hands-on work extending the AI Racing League to use the updated Raspberry Pi 4 computers.

Since last year, generative AI has become much more capable of building out not just single labs or writing small Python programs; it has also been used to generate the foundations of Intelligent Textbooks, including: 1. How to generate modern course descriptions built around moving from knowledge to content generation (Bloom's Taxonomy).

  1. How to generate a detailed enumerated list of Learning Concepts for a specific course or subject matter

  2. A dependency graph of these Learning Concepts indicating the order in which they should be taught to achieve specific objectives

  3. A taxonomy of Learning Concepts allowing the classification and grouping of similar concepts

  4. Tools to visualize, edit, and certify  these Learning Concepts with Subject-Matter Experts

  5. Hooks to allow lesson plans to be customized to the needs of a project, group, or individual student

  6. Frameworks to allow custom simulations to facilitate learning of complex concepts (MicroSims)

I propose to have each student in this project select one course at the University of Minnesota EECD department and work with a subject-matter expert to generate an intelligent textbook for this course. Note: Students will be required to use GitHub and GitHub pages to publish the content.  Although familiarity with GitHub is not required, it is necessary to complete these projects.

docs.title: Why This is Important
docs.text: Today, many courses still use costly printed textbooks.  These textbooks are rigid and force a learner's learning order.  Static textbooks don't promote the use of adaptive learning.  Building many advanced search and indexing tools using generative AI is now possible with just a few sample prompts.  We can now rate online courses on a scale of 1 to 5 and see if students prefer level 5 textbooks.

docs.title: References
docs.text:

  • Learning Graphs
  • MicroSims
  • Circuits
  • Signal Processing
  • Deep Learning

docs.title: University of Minnesota Spring Semester Senior Design Project
docs.text:
The Electrical Engineering and Computer Design department at the University of Minnesota teachers a Senior Design course each Spring Semester. This year, I have been asked to mentor four students for a project that I submitted to Sharat Bhatra last fall.

Original Proposal in Markdown

Link to Google Docs Proposal

docs.title: 2026 Spring Semester Senior Design Project
docs.text:
Project Name: Intelligent Textbooks for Electrical Engineering

Facilitator: Dan McCreary

Summary: This project will allow participating students to create a set of intelligent textbooks that embrace the modern use of generative AI. The output of this project will be the foundation of an intelligent textbook for each student who participates.  Students will gain a deep understanding of how to use Claude Code Skills that extract precise knowledge from large-language models and store this information in an open format on GitHub with a textbook rendered on GitHub pages.  No prior programming experience is required, but students must work with faculty that are subject-matter experts in a specific course.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Each student must have:

  1. Their own personal public GitHub account.  A University of Minnesota GitHub account will not work
  2. Their own computer that they can install our book building tools (Windows WSL, MacOS or Linux).
  3. The $20/month Pro subscription to Claude Code (required)

docs.title: Details
docs.text:
We propose that one of the groups in the EECD Senior seminar build a series of "Intelligent Textbooks" using generative AI.  Last year, we had two groups participate.  One group built MicroSims and did hands-on work extending the AI Racing League to use the updated Raspberry Pi 4 computers.

This year AI has become much more capable of building out not just single labs or writing small Python programs; it has also been used to generate entire Intelligent Textbooks, including:

  1. A modern and complete course description built around moving from knowledge to content generation (Bloom's Taxonomy) and giving it an objective quality assessment on a scale of 1 to 100.
  2. A detailed enumerated list of Learning Concepts for a specific course or subject matter
  3. A dependency graph of these Learning Concepts indicating the order in which they should be taught to achieve specific objectives
  4. A taxonomy of Learning Concepts allowing the classification and grouping of similar concepts
  5. A process of grouping Learning Concepts into chapters so the chapters flow naturally and are well balanced
  6. A process of generating content for each chapter including the extensive use of non-plain text elements (lists, tables, admonitions, diagrams, infographics, microsims and inline interactive assessments).
  7. Creation of high-quality MicroSims including the generation of metadata for search and reuse of MicroSims in search engines
  8. Generation of supplementary content such as a glossary of terms, FAQs and quizzes.
  9. Tools to visualize, edit, and certify  these Learning Concepts with Subject-Matter Experts
  10. Hooks to allow lesson plans to be customized to the needs of a project, group, or individual student

I propose to have each student in this project select one course at the University of Minnesota EECD department and work with a subject-matter expert to generate an intelligent textbook for this course. Note: Students will be required to use GitHub and GitHub pages to publish the content.  Although familiarity with GitHub is not required, it is necessary to complete these projects.  I will work with each student to make sure they can check in their code to GitHub.

docs.title: Why This is Important
docs.text: Today, many courses still use costly printed textbooks.  These textbooks are rigid and force a learner's learning order.  Static textbooks don't promote the use of adaptive learning.  Building many advanced search and indexing tools using generative AI is now possible by using Skills.  We can now objectively rate online courses on a scale of 1 to 5 and see if students prefer higher  level  textbooks.

docs.title: What the Students Will Learn
docs.text: After completing this project, students will be able to:

docs.title: Remember
docs.text:
• Identify the five levels of intelligent textbooks and their distinguishing characteristics
  • List the core components of a learning graph, including concepts, dependencies, and taxonomies
  • Recall key terminology related to generative AI-assisted instructional design
  • Name the essential tools in the intelligent textbook development stack (GitHub, MkDocs, Claude Code)

docs.title: Understand
docs.text:
• Explain how generative AI extracts and structures domain knowledge for educational purposes
  • Describe the relationship between learning concepts and their prerequisite dependencies
  • Summarize how Bloom's Taxonomy guides the progression from knowledge recall to content generation
  • Interpret dependency graphs to understand optimal learning sequences

docs.title: Apply
docs.text:
• Use Claude Code Skills to generate structured educational content from large language models
  • Implement MicroSims to create interactive simulations for complex engineering concepts
  • Configure GitHub Pages to publish and host intelligent textbooks
  • Execute the workflow for transforming learning concepts into organized chapters

docs.title: Analyze
docs.text:
• Analyze dependencies between learning concepts to determine optimal teaching sequences
  • Compare the pedagogical effectiveness of static textbooks versus intelligent textbooks
  • Differentiate between various content types (tables, diagrams, simulations) and their appropriate applications
  • Examine generated content for logical consistency and domain accuracy

docs.title: Evaluate
docs.text:
• Assess textbook quality using objective metrics on a scale of 1 to 100
  • Critique AI-generated content for technical accuracy with subject-matter experts
  • Judge the appropriateness of learning concept groupings within chapters
  • Appraise the balance and flow of chapter organization in a complete textbook

docs.title: Create
docs.text:
• Design a complete intelligent textbook structure for an electrical engineering course or other topic of their choosing
  • Develop custom MicroSims that facilitate understanding of domain-specific concepts
  • Construct comprehensive learning graphs with validated concept dependencies
  • Produce supplementary materials including glossaries, FAQs, and inline assessments
  • Author original educational content that integrates multiple media types and interactive elements

docs.title: Academic Papers:
docs.text:
Five Levels of Intelligent Textbooks: https://osf.io/preprints/edarxiv/sh2yu_v1

MicroSims: A Framework for AI-Generated, Scalable Educational Simulations with Universal Embedding and Adaptive Learning Support: https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.19864

docs.title: Agentic Pipeline
docs.text:
Prompt

I want to build intelligent textbook centered around a learning graph in a graph database. I have many prompts that I use with generative AI LLMs to create and refine these concept dependency graphs (DAGs) from course descriptions to enumerated concepts for the course to the DAGs. How can I automate this with a local LLM on a GPU. My language is Python.

Sample Prompt
